nav.slogan: SKIN DISEASE CLASSIFICATION USING EXPLAINABLE AI

mainHero.subtitle: Skin disease classification using explainable AI
mainHero.description: Upload a photo of the affected skin and the system will not only identify the type of disease but also provide a clear explanation of the result

instructionSteps.title: How does it work?
instructionSteps.uploadDesc: Take a clear photo of the affected skin area and upload it to the system.
instructionSteps.analysisDesc: The system will analyze the image and predict the most likely skin condition among 7 possible classes.
instructionSteps.resultsDesc: Choose one of the explainable AI methods to see which areas of the image the model focused on.

features.autoClassificationDesc: Our system automatically detects one of seven types of dermatological diseases from a skin image. Simply upload an image and receive a preliminary diagnosis.
features.xaiDesc: We don’t just provide an answer — we explain it. Choose any explainable AI method such as Grad-CAM, LIME, SHAP, or Integrated Gradients to understand why the model made a specific decision.
features.historyDesc: Save your results in your personal account and revisit them at any time.
features.noRegistrationDesc: We value your time — that’s why core features are available even without creating an account.
features.responsiveDesc: A user-friendly interface on any device. No complexity — just convenience.

warning.title: Important Notice
warning.description: Our system provides only preliminary disease classification based on AI. Results do not replace doctor consultation. For accurate diagnosis, please consult a dermatologist.

akiec.name: Actinic Keratosis
akiec.description: Precancerous skin lesions caused by prolonged sun exposure.
akiec.symptoms: Rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas, often pink or red.
akiec.treatment: Cryotherapy, topical medications, photodynamic therapy, or surgical removal.

bcc.name: Basal Cell Carcinoma
bcc.description: A common form of skin cancer that grows slowly.
bcc.symptoms: Pearly or waxy bump, flat firm lesion, or brown scar-like area.
bcc.treatment: Surgical excision, Mohs surgery, cryotherapy, or radiation therapy.

bkl.name: Benign Keratosis
bkl.description: Non-cancerous skin growths often associated with aging or sun exposure.
bkl.symptoms: Brown, black, or light tan lesions with a waxy or scaly texture.
bkl.treatment: Typically no treatment needed, but can be removed via cryotherapy or curettage if bothersome.

df.name: Dermatofibroma
df.description: Benign fibrous nodules commonly found on the legs.
df.symptoms: Small, firm, red-brown bumps that may dimple when pinched.
df.treatment: Usually no treatment required, but can be surgically removed if symptomatic.

mel.name: Melanoma
mel.description: A dangerous type of skin cancer that develops from melanocytes.
mel.symptoms: A new spot or an existing mole that changes in size, shape, or color.
mel.treatment: Surgical removal, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy.

nv.name: Melanocytic Nevi
nv.description: Commonly known as moles, formed by clusters of pigment cells.
nv.symptoms: Small dark brown spots caused by clusters of pigment-producing cells.
nv.treatment: Generally no treatment needed, but suspicious moles should be evaluated by a doctor.

vasc.name: Vascular Lesions
vasc.description: Lesions formed by abnormal blood vessels.
vasc.symptoms: Red or purple marks on the skin, which may be flat or raised.
vasc.treatment: Laser therapy, surgical intervention, or medications depending on the type.
